titleStmt.title: Distributed Event-Triggered Adaptive Control for Consensus of Linear Multi-Agent Systems with External Disturbances

analytic.title: Distributed Event-Triggered Adaptive Control for Consensus of Linear Multi-Agent Systems with External Disturbances

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper investigates the consensus problem of linear multi-agent systems subject to external disturbances via distributed event-triggered adaptive control. First, a distributed event-triggered adaptive output feedback control strategy is proposed for each agent. It is shown that under this control strategy, the consensus problem can be solved for any connected undirected communication graph in a fully distributed manner without using any global information. Then a distributed selftriggered adaptive output feedback control strategy is designed with which continuous monitoring of the measurement error is no longer needed. It is further shown that for the proposed event-triggered and self-triggered control strategies, no agent will exhibit Zeno behavior. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed two control strategies is illustrated on a group of two-mass-spring systems.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: I N the past two decades, multi-agent systems (MASs) have been extensively investigated due to their potential applications in a wide range of areas, such as rendezvous, formation, flocking, and sensor networks, to name just a few [1]. A large volume of works focus on the consensus problem of MASs, that is, to design a control strategy such that a group of agents agree on a certain quantity of interest (see [1]- [7] and the references therein). In practical MASs, external disturbances widely exist and affect the system performance. Therefore, it is of great importance to study the consensus problem for MASs in the presence of external disturbances. Due to various physical constraints such as wide spatial distribution of agents and constrained communication ranges, it is desirable to design fully distributed control strategies for MASs. In other words, each agent can only use the information of itself and its neighbors in the design and implementation of its controller.

Various distributed control strategies have been developed for consensus of MASs with general linear dynamics, which are referred to as linear MASs (see [8]- [11]). It is observed that the control strategies in [8] and [9] were designed by utilizing some information on eigenvalues of the Laplacian matrix corresponding to the communication graph. However, these eigenvalues are actually global information, in the sense that all agents must know the entire network topology. To avoid using the global information, fully distributed adaptive control strategies were proposed in [10] and [11] for linear MASs. The basic idea is to find an adaptive law such that the coupling gain corresponding to each edge or node in the communication graph is dynamically updated. It is noted that the aforementioned distributed control strategies are often implemented by conventional periodic sampling control, which is also referred to as time-triggered control. However, in many practical cases, individual agents may be equipped with simple embedded microprocessors, which typically have limited on-board energy resources. By using a time-triggered control strategy, unnecessary fast sampling has to be taken in order to ensure the satisfactory performance of the concerned system, which often leads to excessive energy consumption and thus shortens the system's operational lifespan. To deal with this issue, as an attractive alternative, event-triggered control can be taken into consideration. Using this control approach, the control task is executed only when a prescribed triggering condition is violated. As shown in [12] and [13], event-triggered control has more advantages than periodic sampling control when handling energy resource constraints. This is because the efficiency of resource utilization can be improved under event-triggered control strategies, while still guaranteeing a satisfactory control performance.

In [14], an event-triggered control strategy was developed to stabilize a single system. Based on [14], a distributed eventtriggered control strategy was proposed in [15] such that a group of single-integrators can achieve average consensus, and the result was further extended to a self-triggered setup. From then on, consensus of MASs has been widely investigated via distributed event-triggered control. At the beginning, many relevant works focused on MASs with simple dynamics, for instance, single or double integrator dynamics (see [15]- [21]). It is noted that in [18], a combined measurement approach was presented for event design and a novel distributed eventtriggered control strategy was developed. Under this control strategy, the communication load among neighboring agents 2168-2267 c 2018 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

can be significantly reduced. Recently, a number of eventtriggered control strategies have been developed for consensus of linear MASs (see [22]- [31]). In particular, by using the combined measurement approach as in [18], the consensus problem was addressed in [26] and [29] for linear MASs with and without a leader, respectively. It should be pointed out that among those control strategies in [22]- [30], some eigenvalue information of the Laplacian matrix is required to be known for each agent. To be specific, for the cases with undirected communication graphs in [24]- [27] and [29], the second smallest eigenvalue or the largest eigenvalue of the Laplacian matrix is required to be known; for the cases with directed communication graphs in [22], [23], and [28]- [30], the smallest positive real part of the eigenvalues of the Laplacian matrix is required to be known. All this eigenvalue information is global information. Therefore, the event-triggered control strategies in the aforementioned works are not fully distributed. Most recently, two fully distributed event-triggered control strategies have been proposed in [32] and [33] to address the consensus problem for homogeneous linear MASs and heterogeneous linear MASs, respectively. However, to the best of our knowledge, fully distributed event-triggered control strategies are yet to be developed for linear MASs in the presence of external disturbances. Motivated by the above observations, we will design fully distributed event-triggered and self-triggered control strategies for consensus of linear MASs subject to external disturbances. In practice, agents' states are not always available. Instead, agents' outputs are often available. By utilizing the so-called σ -modification technique, a distributed eventtriggered adaptive output feedback control strategy is first designed. Furthermore, to avoid continuously monitoring the measurement error, a distributed self-triggered adaptive output feedback control strategy is developed. It is shown that by the proposed two control strategies, no agent will exhibit Zeno behavior. Compared with the previous works, the main contributions of this paper are at least threefold. First, compared with [10] and [11], the consensus problem can be solved for linear MASs with intermittent communication. Consequently, the communication load among neighboring agents is significantly reduced. Second, compared with most existing strategies [22], [24]- [26], [28]- [30], the proposed event-triggered control strategy is fully distributed, without requiring any global information. Last but not least, the proposed event-triggered control strategy can deal with linear MASs with bounded external disturbances, unlike those existing works, except for [30] where external disturbances are required to satisfy the restrictive matching condition.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces some preliminaries and formulates the consensus problem. The main results are provided in Sections III and IV. Section III presents a distributed event-triggered adaptive control strategy and discusses the feasibility of the proposed event-triggering mechanism by excluding Zeno behavior. Subsequently, the event-triggered result is extended to the self-triggered setup in Section IV. In Section V, numerical simulations of a practical example illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed two control strategies. Finally, some conclusions are given in Section VI.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES AND PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: Notation: For a vector x ∈ R n , x denotes its Euclidean norm. For a square matrix A ∈ R n×n , A T , A , λ min (A), and λ max (A) represent its transpose, induced 2-norm, minimal eigenvalue, and maximal eigenvalue, respectively. If A is positive definite (or semidefinite), denote A > 0 (or A ≥ 0). The Kronecker product of two matrices is represented by A ⊗ B. Let I n be the n × n identity matrix and N be the set of all non-negative integers. 1 N is an N-dimensional column vector with all elements being 1. For vectors x i ∈ R n , i = 1, . . . , N, col(x 1 , . . . , x N ) stands for a column vector which stacks all x i together. Given some scalar a i , i = 1, . . . , N, a diagonal matrix with the diagonal elements being a i , i = 1, . . . , N, is denoted as diag{a 1 , . . . , a N }. For a function f : [0, ∞) → R, its upper right-hand derivative is defined by
div.formula: D + f (t) = lim sup s→0 + ((f (t + s) -f (t))/s). If f (t)
div.p: is not differentiable at point t 0 , then ḟ (t 0 ) stands for D + f (t 0 ).

div.head: A. Algebraic Graph Theory
div.p: Let G = (N , E) be a graph, where N = {1, . . . , N} is a finite nonempty set of nodes and E ⊆ N × N is a set of edges. If there exist two nodes i and j such that (j, i) ∈ E, then they are said to be adjacent, and node j is called as a neighbor of node i. The neighbor set of node i is defined by
div.formula: N i = {j ∈ N | (j, i) ∈ E}.
div.p: The graph G is said to be undirected, if and only if (i, j) ∈ E implies that (j, i) ∈ E, for any i, j ∈ N . Let the adjacency matrix associated with G be denoted as A = [a ij ] ∈ R N×N , where a ii = 0, a ij = 1, if (j, i) ∈ E, and a ij = 0, otherwise. A path of G is defined as an ordered sequence of distinct nodes {i 1 , i 2 , . . . , i m } such that (i k , i k+1 ) ∈ E, for k = 1, 2, . . . , m -1. If there is a path between any two nodes of G, then G is said to be connected. Let d i be the degree of node i, which represents the number of its neighboring nodes. For the graph G, define the degree matrix as D = diag{d 1 , . . . , d N }, and the Laplacian matrix as L = D -A. If the graph G is undirected, then the corresponding Laplacian matrix L is symmetric and positive semidefinite, i.e., L = L T ≥ 0. Furthermore, if the graph G is connected, then its Laplacian matrix L has a simple zero eigenvalue with other eigenvalues being strictly positive, that is, 0 = λ 1 < λ 2 ≤ • • • ≤ λ N . Note that the eigenvalue λ 2 > 0 is the well-known algebraic connectivity of G.

div.head: B. Problem Formulation
div.p: Consider a linear MAS consisting of N identical agents. The dynamics of the ith agent are given by
div.formula: ẋi (t) = Ax i (t) + Bu i (t) + Ew i (t) y i (t) = Cx i (t) (1)
div.p: where [30] as its special case, when the external disturbances are matched, i.e., B = E. It is assumed that the agents' states cannot be measured, and each agent can make use of its own output information. In this paper, the objective is to design fully distributed event-triggered and self-triggered output feedback control strategies for consensus of the linear MAS (1). More specifically, the consensus problem is defined as follows.
div.formula: x i (t) ∈ R n , u i (t) ∈ R p , y i (t) ∈ R q ,
div.p: Definition 1 (Consensus Problem): Consider the linear MAS (1) subject to external disturbances with a fixed undirected graph G. Given any initial conditions x i (0), i ∈ N , if the agents' states satisfy the following condition:
div.formula: lim t→∞ sup x i (t) -x j (t) ≤ 0 , ∀i, j ∈ N (2
div.p: where 0 is a tunable parameter, then the consensus problem is said to be solved for system (1). Moreover, if ( 2) is satisfied with lim t→∞ x i (t) = 0, for any i ∈ N , then the consensus problem is trivially solved, otherwise it is nontrivially solved.
In what follows, some key facts are summarized, which will be used in the sequel.

Lemma 1 (Young's Inequality [34]): If there are two positive real numbers p and q satisfying (1/p) + (1/q) = 1, then for any two non-negative real numbers a and b, there holds ab ≤ (a p /p) + (b q /q).
Lemma 2 [35]: Suppose that D, S, and P are some real matrices with appropriate dimensions and P is positive definite. Then, for any vectors x, y ∈ R n 2x T DSy ≤ x T DPD T x + y T S T P -1 Sy.

To proceed, the following assumptions are introduced. Assumption 1: The pair (A, B) is stabilizable. Assumption 2: The pair (A, C) is detectable. Assumption 3: The communication graph G is undirected and connected.
Assumption 4: The external disturbances are bounded, that is, there exists a positive constant wi , such that w i (t) ≤ wi , for all t ≥ 0 and i ∈ N .

div.head: III. DISTRIBUTED EVENT-TRIGGERED ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY
div.p: In this section, to address the consensus problem of linear MASs, we will propose a distributed event-triggered adaptive output feedback control strategy, which is robust to external disturbances.

div.head: A. Adaptive Control Law Design
div.p: For each agent, the following distributed event-triggered adaptive output feedback control law is proposed:
div.formula: υi (t) = Aυ i (t) + Bu i (t) + F(Cυ i (t) -y i (t)) (3a) ξi (t) = Aξ i (t) + c i (t)BK N j=1 a ij ξ i t i k -ξ j t i k (3b) ċi (t) = -ϕ i c i (t) + ⎡ ⎣ N j=1 a ij ξ i t i k -ξ j t i k ⎤ ⎦ T × ⎡ ⎣ N j=1 a ij ξ i t i k -ξ j t i k ⎤ ⎦ (3c) u i (t) = K(υ i (t) -ξ i (t)) (3d) for t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 )
div.p: , where υ i (t) ∈ R n is the state of the observer, ξ i (t) ∈ R n is the state of the compensator, F, K, and are the feedback gain matrices to be determined, c i (t) is the adaptive coupling gain corresponding to agent i with c i (0) > 0, ϕ i is some small positive constant, and t i k is the kth triggering time instant of agent i, for k ∈ N. The design of the adaptive law (3c) is partly motivated by the so-called σ -modification technique in robust adaptive control [36]. With this adaptive law, the parameter drift phenomenon of the coupling gain can be avoided.
To introduce the event-triggering mechanism, define the combined measurement [18] as
div.formula: z i (t) = N j=1 a ij ξ i (t) -ξ j (t)(4)
div.p: and the measurement error as
div.formula: e i (t) = z i t i k -z i (t), t ∈ t i k , t i k+1 (5
div.p: for agent i, i ∈ N . Let the sequence of event-triggering time instants of agent i be denoted by {t i k : k ∈ N}. Then, the proposed event-triggering mechanism is given as follows. The next triggering time instant t i k+1 is determined by
div.formula: t i k+1 = inf t > t i k | e i (t) = γ i Kz i t i k + β i e -α i t (6)
div.p: where γ i , β i , and α i are the parameters to be designed later. Under this triggering mechanism, an event is triggered for agent i, whenever the term e i (t) crosses the threshold
div.formula: γ i Kz i (t i k ) + β i e -α i t .
div.p: Note that e i (t) is reset to zero once an event occurs for agent i. This can be easily seen from its definition in (5). It should be pointed out that under the adaptive control law (3a)-(3d) and the event-triggering mechanism (6), agent i only needs to transmit the compensator state ξ i (t) to all its neighbors via inter-agent communication.
For agent i, define the observer error as
div.formula: xi (t) = υ i (t) -x i (t). Let zi (t) be the latest sampling value of z i (t) at time t, that is, zi (t) = z i (t i k ), for t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ). Then, it follows from (1) and (3a)-(3d) that for t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ) ẋi (t) = (A + FC)x i (t) -Ew i (t) ξi (t) = Aξ i (t) + c i (t)BKz i (t) ċi (t) = -ϕ i c i (t) + zT i (t) zi (t) υi (t) = (A + BK)υ i (t) -BKξ i (t) + FCx i (t). (7
div.p: Define
div.formula: q i (t) = N j=1 a ij (x i (t) -x j (t)), η i (t) = N j=1 a ij (υ i (t) - υ j (t)), and ε i (t) = N j=1 a ij (x i (t) -xj (t)). Let x(t) = col(x 1 (t), . . ., x N (t)), υ(t) = col(υ 1 (t), . . ., υ N (t)), x(t) = col(x 1 (t), . . ., xN (t)), ξ(t) = col(ξ 1 (t), . . ., ξ N (t)), q(t) = col(q 1 (t), . . ., q N (t)), η(t) = col(η 1 (t), . . ., η N (t)), ε(t) = col(ε 1 (t), . . ., ε N (t)), z(t) = col(z 1 (t), . . ., z N (t)), z(t) = col(z 1 (t), . . ., zN (t)), e(t) = col(e 1 (t), . . ., e N (t)), w(t) = col(w 1 (t), . . ., w N (t)), and c(t) = diag{c 1 (t), . . ., c N (t)}. Then, one has q(t) = (L⊗I n )x(t), η(t) = (L⊗I n )υ(t), ε(t) = (L⊗I n )x(t), and z(t) = (L⊗I n )ξ(t).
div.p: Obviously, q(t) = η(t) -ε(t) and z(t) = z(t) + e(t). According to Definition 1, it is seen that the consensus problem can be solved if and only if q(t) is uniformly ultimately bounded. Hereafter, q(t) will be referred to as the consensus error. By (7), the closed-loop system can be written in the following compact form:
div.formula: ε(t) = [I N ⊗ (A + FC)]ε(t) -(L ⊗ E)w(t) (8a) ξ(t) = (I N ⊗ A)ξ(t) + (c(t) ⊗ BK)z(t) (8b) ċi (t) = -ϕ i c i (t) + zT i (t) zi (t) (8c) η(t) = [I N ⊗ (A + BK)]η(t) -(L ⊗ BK)ξ(t) + (I N ⊗ FC)ε(t). (8d

div.head: B. Event-Triggering Mechanism Design
div.p: Now, we are in a position to design a novel event-triggering mechanism in the form of ( 6) so that the consensus problem can be solved for system (1). The proposed event-triggering mechanism is summarized in the following theorem.

Theorem 1: Consider the linear MAS (1) with the adaptive control law (3a)-(3d) under Assumptions 1-4. Let F = -P 1 C T , where P 1 = P T 1 > 0 is the solution of the algebraic Riccati equation (ARE) 9) Let K = -B T P 2 and = P 2 BB T P 2 , where P 2 = P T 2 > 0 is the solution of the ARE

div.p: It can be verified that ψ(t) is bounded, and hence V(t) is bounded. Similar to (18), one has

div.p: Thus, by the definition of V(t), V(t) is lower bounded by
div.formula: V(t) ≥ φ 1 λ min P -1 1 ε(t) 2 + φ 2 λ N λ min (P 2 ) z(t) 2 + φ 2 N i=1 (c i (t) -c 0 ) 2 + λ min (P 2 ) η(t) 2 . (34
div.p: Combining ( 33) and ( 34) together, it is concluded that ε(t), z(t), c(t), and η(t) in the overall closed-loop system are uniformly ultimately bounded. Since q(t) = η(t) -ε(t), q(t) 2 ≤ 2 ε(t) 2 + 2 η(t) 2 . Thus, the consensus error q(t) is also uniformly ultimately bounded.
The ultimate bound of q(t) is given as follows. Note that (29) can be rewritten as
div.formula: V(t) ≤ -V(t) -χ q(t) 2 + φ 2 θ e -2α min t +(35)
div.p: with
div.formula: χ = 1 2 min 1 -φ 1 λ max P -1 1 , 1 2 λ min (Q 2 ) -λ max (P 2 ) . (36
div.p: If q(t) 2 ≥ (φ 2 θ e -2α min t + )/χ , then it follows from (35) that V(t) ≤ -V(t). Therefore, the consensus error q(t) exponentially converges to a neighborhood of the origin, i.e., D = {q(t) : q(t) 2 ≤ /χ}, with a convergence rate faster than e -t . The proof is thus completed. Remark 1: It is noted that the ultimate bound of the consensus error q(t) depends on the agents' dynamics, the communication graph, the bounds of the external disturbances, and the choice of the parameters ϕ i , i = 1, . . . , N. From the residual set D, it can be seen that by decreasing the convergence rate or the residual term , the ultimate bound of q(t) can be reduced. For a given MAS and a prefixed communication graph, larger bounds wi , i = 1, . . . , N result in larger . Besides, by choosing relatively small ϕ i , i = 1, . . . , N, the values of and can be adjusted to be relatively small. Therefore, the ultimate bound of q(t) can be adjusted by choosing suitable parameters ϕ i , i = 1, . . . , N. On the other hand, it is worth noting that the ultimate bound of q(t) is independent of the triggering parameters γ i , β i , and α i , i = 1, . . . , N, which only affect the number of events for each agent.
For the case when the external disturbances are absent, by Theorem 1, we have the following corollary.

Corollary 1: Consider the linear MAS (1) without external disturbances under Assumptions 1-3. Let the design parameters be the same as those in Theorem 1. Then, the consensus problem can be solved by the adaptive control law (3a)-(3d) and the event-triggering condition (11). Moreover, the consensus error q(t) exponentially converges to the bounded set D = {q(t) : q(t) 2 ≤ (φ 2 /χ ) N i=1 ϕ i c 2 0 }. Remark 2: In Corollary 1, the norm of the consensus error cannot decay to zero. This is because the term -ϕ i c i (t) is added into (3c) to avoid the parameter drift phenomenon by the so-called σ -modification technique [36]. In real implementations, by choosing sufficiently small ϕ i , i = 1, . . . , N, the consensus error q(t) can converge to an arbitrarily small neighborhood of zero. Moreover, if there is no disturbance, then the term -ϕ i c i (t) relevant to the σ -modification technique is not needed in (3c), and in this case, the consensus error can converge to zero.

div.head: C. Feasibility Analysis
div.p: In this section, we aim to analyze the feasibility of the proposed event-triggering mechanism by excluding Zeno behavior, that is, a phenomenon of an infinite number of events in a finite time interval. The result is summarized in the following theorem.

Theorem 2: Consider the linear MAS (1) with the adaptive control law (3a)-(3d) under Assumptions 1-4. Let the feedback gain matrices F, K, and be designed as in Theorem 1. Then, under the eventtriggering condition (11), no agent will exhibit Zeno behavior.

Proof: The claim is proven by contradiction. Suppose that there is at least one agent which exhibits Zeno behavior. Without loss of generality, assume that agent i exhibits Zeno behavior, for i ∈ N . Then, by the definition of Zeno execution for hybrid systems [38], there exists a finite time T i such that t i k ≤ T i for all k ∈ N and lim k→∞ t i k = T i . According to the definition of limits, for any i > 0, there exists a positive integer M i such that T ii < t i m ≤ T i , for any m ≥ M i . Consider the time evolution of e i (t) on each interval [t i k , t i k+1 ), k ∈ N. By (5), ėi (t) = -ż i (t). Thus, the upper right-hand derivative of e i (t) over [t i k , t i k+1 ) is obtained as
div.formula: D + e i (t) = e T i (t)ė i (t) e i (t) ≤ ėi (t) = żi (t) = Az i (t) + N j=1 a ij BK c i (t)z i t i k -c j (t)z j t j k
div.p: ≤ A e i (t) + αi (t) (37) where k arg max l∈N {t j l |t j l ≤ t}, and αi (t)
div.formula: Az i (t i k ) + N j=1 a ij BK(c i (t)z i (t i k ) -c j (t)z j (t j k ))
div.p: . From the proof of Theorem 1, it can be seen that c i (t) and z i (t), i ∈ N , are bounded. Thus, there exists a positive constant i such that αi (t) ≤ i , for all t ∈ [0, ∞). It follows from (37) that:
div.formula: D + e i (t) ≤ A e i (t) + i . (38
div.p: By using the comparison lemma and noting that e i (t i k ) = 0, an upper bound of e i (t) for t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ) is given by
div.formula: e i (t) ≤ i A e A t-t i k -1 . (39
div.p: Under the event-triggering condition (11), an event is triggered for agent i when e i (t) crosses the threshold γ i Kz i (t i k ) + β i e -α i t . Hence, by (39) i A e
div.formula: A t i k+1 -t i k -1 ≥ κ i 2 c2 i + 1 e -α i T i (40)
div.p: with ci being the maximum value of c i (t). Consider the case when k ≥ M i . Letting
div.formula: i = 1 2 A ln A i κ i 2 c2 i + 1 e -α i T i + 1 one has from (40) that t i k+1 -t i k ≥ 2 i , which implies that t i k+1 ≥ t i k +2 i > T i + i .
div.p: This contradicts the fact that T ii < t i k+1 ≤ T i . Consequently, Zeno behavior is excluded for any agent i. This completes the proof.

Remark 3: By introducing an exponential decay function β i e -α i t in the event-triggering condition (11), Zeno behavior can be excluded for each agent. This design idea is similar to that in [23], which deals with the leader-follower consensus problem. However, different from that in [23], the decay rate α i in this paper does not need to satisfy the constraint α i < ᾱ, where ᾱ > 0 depends on the communication graph.

Remark 4: It is worth mentioning that the event-triggering mechanism proposed in this paper has three distinctive features. First, by virtue of the combined measurement approach in [18], each agent is triggered only at its own triggering time. In other words, the triggering of an agent is independent of that of other agents. Consequently, the number of information transmission among neighboring agents can be significantly reduced, as shown in [18]. Second, the proposed event-triggering mechanism is fully distributed. More specifically, the parameters in the triggering condition (11) are independent of any global information such as the eigenvalue information of the Laplacian matrix. Finally, all agents can be triggered in an asynchronous fashion.

Remark 5: In [30], a distributed event-triggered control strategy was developed for linear MASs with external disturbances. The differences between the control strategy proposed in this paper and that in [30] are stated as follows. First, compared with the state feedback control strategy in [30], the proposed control strategy is based on output information of each agent. Second, the proposed control strategy is designed and implemented in a fully distributed manner, while that in [30] needs some global information, for instance, the information on eigenvalues of the Laplacian matrix and the total number of agents. Third, the proposed control strategy can deal with the cases with bounded external disturbances, while that in [30] requires the external disturbances to satisfy the restrictive matching condition.

div.head: IV. DISTRIBUTED SELF-TRIGGERED ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY
div.p: The event-triggered control strategy proposed in the previous section suffers a drawback that during its implementation, each agent has to continuously monitor the measurement error. That is, agent i still needs to continuously measure the compensator state ξ j , for all j ∈ N i . Therefore, the communication load among agents may not be reduced as desired. To overcome this drawback, a self-triggering algorithm, in which the next triggering time can be precomputed based on the information available at the current time for each agent, is proposed in this section.

The idea is to calculate the next triggering time t i k+1 using the information available for agent i in [t i k , t i k+1 ). First, we present a sufficient condition to guarantee that the triggering condition (11) holds. According to the adaptive law (3c), the coupling gain c i (t) can be expressed as
div.formula: c i (t) = 1 ϕ i z T i t i k z i t i k + c i t i k - 1 ϕ i z T i t i k z i t i k e -ϕ i t-t i k (41) for t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ). Denote μ i k = 1 ϕ i z T i t i k z i t i k + c i t i k - 1 ϕ i z T i t i k z i t i k .
div.p: Then, one has
div.formula: |c i (t)| ≤ μ i k , for t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ). Hence, γ i ≥ σ i /[2((μ i k ) 2 + 1)
div.p: ] and
]. Define the following self-triggering function:
div.formula: h i (t) = e i (t) - √ σ i Kz i t i k + √ κ i e -α i t 2 μ i k 2 + 1 (42) for t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ).
div.p: It can be seen that h i (t) ≤ 0 is sufficient to guarantee (11). Therefore, h i (t) ≤ 0 can be regarded as a more conservative triggering condition than (11), in the sense that the triggering condition h i (t) ≤ 0 will yield more events for each agent in comparison with (11) in general.

To establish the self-triggering algorithm, we next consider the triggering condition h i (t) ≤ 0, and compute the time evolution of h i (t) over the time interval [t i k , t i k+1 ). By ( 37) and ( 41), the upper right-hand derivative D + h i (t) satisfies the following differential inequality:
div.formula: D + h i (t) ≤ A e i (t) + βi (t) + α i √ κ i e -α i t 2 μ i k 2 + 1 (43) for t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ), where βi (t) ( A + d i μ i k BK ) z i (t i k ) + N j=1 a ij μ j k BK z j (t j k ) .
div.p: Considering the event-triggering condition (11), D + h i (t) can be further bounded by
div.formula: D + h i (t) ≤ A γ i Kz i t i k + β i e -α i t + βi (t) + α i √ κ i e -α i t 2 μ i k 2 + 1 ≤ ρ i e -α i t + ω i (t)(44)
div.p: where
div.formula: ρ i √ κ i /(2 ) A + α i / (μ i k ) 2 + 1and
ω i (t) √ σ i /2 A z i (t i k ) + βi (t). It is noted that ω i (t) remains to be ω i (t i k ), until new z j (t j k
div.p: ) and c j (t j k ) are received from any of its neighbors. Suppose that the updating time instants for ω i (t) over the time interval [t i k , t i k+1 ] are denoted as
div.formula: {t i 0 , ti 1 , . . . , ti m }, with m ≥ 1, ti 0 = t i k and ti m = t i k+1 . Since e i (t i k ) = 0, one has h i t i k = - √ σ i Kz i t i k + √ κ i e -α i t i k 2 μ i k 2 + 1 . Then, for all t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ] h i (t) ≤ h i t i k+1 = t i k+1 t i k ḣi (t)dt + h i t i k = m-1 l=0 ti l+1 ti l ρ i e -α i t + ω i (t) dt + h i t i k = 0. (45
div.p: To calculate the next triggering time instant t i k+1 , an iterative algorithm is proposed for agent i as follows. Let
div.formula: ti l+1 ti l ρ i e -α i t + ω i (t) dt = s i k ti l (46)
div.p: where s i k (t i l ) satisfies
div.formula: s i k ti l = s i k ti l-1 - ti l ti l-1 ρ i e -α i t + ω i (t) dt (47) with s i k (t i 0 ) = -h i (t i k ).
div.p: Then, (46) can be rewritten as follows:
div.formula: ρ i α i e -α i ti l 1 -e -α i ti l+1 -t i l + ω i ti l ti l+1 -ti l = s i k ti l . (48
div.p: At the start, set l = 0, ti 0 = t i k , and solve (48) with ti l = ti 0 to obtain the solution ti l+1 . For t ∈ (t i l , ti l+1 ), if there is no event triggered for agent j, j ∈ N i , then set t i k+1 = ti l+1 ; otherwise, if any neighboring agent j is triggered at time t ∈ (t i l , ti l+1 ), agent i needs to update the variable ω i (t). In this case, set l = l + 1, ti l = t , and solve (48) with the new ti l to obtain the solution ti l+1 . Repeat this procedure until there is no neighboring agent Algorithm 1 Self-Triggering Algorithm for All Agents Initialization For each agent i, i ∈ N , set k i = 0, T i = t i 0 , s i k i = -h i (t i 0 ), l i = 0, and ti l i = t i 0 ; calculate ω i (t i l i ); solve (48) to obtain the solution ti l i +1 . Iteration 1: while t < T * do 2:
i = arg min i ti l i +1 ;
div.formula: for j = 1, • • • , N do 4: if j = i then 5: set k j = k j + 1, t j k j = tj l j +1 , T j = {T j , t j k j }, s j k j = -h j (t j k j ), l j = 0,
div.p: triggered for t ∈ (t i l , ti l+1 ). Finally, the next triggering time t i k+1 can be calculated as ti l+1 . Let T * be the lifespan of the MAS (1) and T i be the sequence of triggering time instants over the time interval [0, T * ) for agent i, i.e., T i = {t i k i : k i ∈ N}. Then, the proposed self-triggering algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 1. In this algorithm, when an event is triggered for agent i, it needs to send the request to its neighbors for their compensator states ξ j (t), j ∈ N i , to receive the state information, and to send the combined measurement z i (t) and the coupling gain c i (t) to all its neighbors. Thus, each agent needs to execute information transmission at the triggering time instants of itself and its neighbors. It has been shown in [19] that compared with the algorithm in [15], the self-triggering algorithms established by the combined measurement approach can actually reduce the number of information transmission for consensus of single-integrator MASs. It is also expected that the number of information transmission can be reduced under the proposed self-triggering algorithm based on the combined measurement approach.
The following theorem states the result on consensus by the preceding self-triggering algorithm.

Theorem 3: Consider the linear MAS (1) with the adaptive control law (3a)-(3d) under Assumptions 1-4. Let the feedback gain matrices F, K, and be designed as in Theorem 1. If the sequence of triggering time instants for each agent, i.e., T i , i ∈ N , is determined using Algorithm 1, then the consensus problem can be solved for system (1). Furthermore, no agent will exhibit Zeno behavior. Fig. 1. Two-mass-spring system with a disturbance [39].
Proof: The result of this theorem can be directly obtained by Theorems 1 and 2, and thus its proof is omitted.

Remark 6: Following the same line as in Theorem 2, one can prove by contradiction that with the proposed self-triggering algorithm, each agent does not exhibit Zeno behavior. Specifically, for agent i, i ∈ N , consider the time evolution of the self-triggering function h
div.formula: i (t) on each interval [t i k , t i k+1 ), k ∈ N. It should be noted that the term √ κ i e -α i t / 2((μ i k ) 2 + 1)
div.p: in h i (t) plays a vital role in excluding Zeno behavior.

Remark 7: The proposed self-triggering algorithm possesses two important features. One is that at each triggering time t i k , agent i samples the combined measurement z i (t) and the coupling gain c i (t) and then sends the measured information z i (t i k ) and c i (t i k ) to all its neighbors. The other is that for agent i, its next triggering time t i k+1 can be calculated based on its own information at the current triggering time t i k , i.e., z i (t i k ) and c i (t i k ), and the latest received neighboring information, i.e., z j (t j k ) and c j (t j k ), j ∈ N i . It must be pointed out that with the self-triggering algorithm no continuous monitoring is required between any two consecutive triggering time instants.

div.head: V. SIMULATION EXAMPLE
div.p: In this section, the effectiveness of the proposed control strategies will be demonstrated on a group of two-mass-spring systems. For such an MAS with external disturbances, a synchronization problem has been investigated in [39]. Consider the two-mass-spring system as shown in Fig. 1, which consists of two masses that are free to slide on a frictionless surface. This system is controlled via a force u(t) ∈ R acting on mass m 1 and disturbed by an external force w(t) ∈ R acting on mass m 2 . The displacements of these two masses can be measured and used as the output information. The spring stiffness of two springs are k 1 and k 2 , respectively. Define the system state as

where y 1 and ẏ1 denote the displacement and velocity of mass m 1 , respectively; y 2 and ẏ2 denote the displacement and velocity of mass m 2 , respectively. Then, the dynamics of the two-mass-spring system can be described as

It is observed that the dynamics (49) are in the form of (1). Consider the scenario that the MAS consists of five identical two-mass-spring systems in the form of (49), acting as agent i, i = 1, . . . , 5. The communication graph among these five agents is depicted in Fig. 2. Let u i , w i , y 1i , and y 2i be the control input, external disturbance, displacement of mass m 1 , and displacement of mass m 2 , for agent i, respectively. As in [39], the system parameters are set as follows: m 1 = m 2 = 0.75 kg, and k 1 = k 2 = 2 N/m. The external disturbances are assumed to be some sinusoidal signals, i.e., w i (t) = 0.02 sin(0.5t), i = 1, . . . , 5. It can be checked that Assumptions 1-4 are satisfied. Consequently, the proposed two control strategies can be employed to solve the consensus problem for the concerned MAS.

The simulation is carried out with the MATLAB software. Let Q 1 = Q 2 = I 4 . By solving the AREs ( 9) and (10) with the "care" command, the feedback gain matrices F, K, and are obtained as The initial coupling gains and the parameters in the adaptive law and the event-triggering mechanism are chosen as follows: c i (0) = 1, ϕ i = 0.1, σ i = 0.99, κ i = 5, and α i = 0.1, for i = 1, . . . , 5. The initial states for the agents, observers, and compensators can be randomly selected. For convenience, these initial values are randomly chosen over the interval (0, 1) as follows: velocity for two masses m 1 and m 2 are shown in Figs. 3456, respectively, where x i = [x i1 , x i2 , x i3 , x i4 ] T denotes the state of agent i, for i = 1, . . . , 5. The corresponding adaptive coupling gains are depicted in Figs. 7 and8, respectively, which can be observed to be bounded. From the simulation results, it can be seen that the consensus problem is solved under the proposed two control strategies. Moreover, the event-triggering time instants of each agent are presented in Fig. 9.

To study the effect of the parameters ϕ i , i = 1, . . . , 5 on the consensus performance, consider the event-triggered and selftriggered cases with different ϕ i . The norm of the consensus error q(t) in the event-triggered case is shown in Fig. 10. For the self-triggered case, the result is similar to Fig. 10 and hence is omitted here. Note that the smaller the ultimate bound of q(t), the better the consensus performance. It is thus verified that the consensus performance can be improved by decreasing the values of ϕ i , i = 1, . . . , 5.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we have investigated the consensus problem for linear MASs with external disturbances under fixed undirected graphs. First, for each agent, a distributed eventtriggered adaptive output feedback control strategy has been proposed. It has been shown that the consensus problem can be solved and the consensus error converges to an adjustable neighborhood of the origin. Then, to relax the requirement of continuous monitoring, a distributed self-triggered adaptive output feedback control strategy has been further proposed. It has also been shown that the occurrence of Zeno behavior can be prevented for each agent for the proposed two control strategies. A key feature of the proposed two control strategies in comparison with existing event-based strategies is that they are fully distributed, without requiring any global information. Future work can be directed to more general agent dynamics such as heterogeneous linear MASs or more general communication topologies.
